page.title: 19SCUTCH MILL, KILWAUGHTER
page.content: Harvey's waterwheel provides power for two mills - the second being the {Scutch Mill,}no longer used. When {Ulster Linen}was a great industry, {flax}was grown locally. After pulling, the flax plants were{"retted"}in dams, to break up the coating. After rett- ing, the flax was taken for{scutching. The scutchers stood in a row of little "sentry boxes" feeding the flax into{ {rollers}which broke away the {husks, leaving the fibres or{tow.}The job was hard, in the choking, dusty atmos- phere. The scutchers' favourite drink was metholated spirits. Sadly, little flax is now grown, but a revival of world interest in Irish Linen may bring it back as a crop. Then Harvey's Scutch Mill may re-awaken to the rush of water, the whirr of belts, and the grinding of rollers, cleaning the linen fibres.
